File.Title: Organization of Projections From the Medial Nucleus of the Amygdala: A PHAL Study in the Rat
File.Authors: N.S. CANTERAS, R.B. SIMERLY, AND L.W. SWANSON

Abstract.S: The organization of axonal projections from the four recognized parts of the medial amygdalar nucleus (MEA) were characterized with the Phaesolus uulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHAL) method in male rats.
The results indicate that the MEA consists of two major divisions, ventral and dorsal, and that the former may also consist of rostra1 and caudal regions.

As a whole, the MEA generates centrifugal projections to several parts of the accessory and main olfactory sensory pathways, and projections to a) several parts of the intrahippocampal circuit (ventrally); b) the ventral striatum, ventral pallidum, and bed nuclei of the stria terminalis (BST) in the basal telencephaon; c) many parts of the hypothalamus; d) midline and medial parts of the thalamus; and e) the periaqueductal gray, ventral tegmental area, and midbrain raphe.

The dorsal division of the MEA (the posterodorsal part) is characterized by projections to the principal nucleus of the BST, and to the anteroventral periventricular, medial, and central parts of the medial preoptic, and ventral premammillary hypothalamic nuclei.
These hypothalamic nuclei project heavily to neuroendocrine and autonomic-related parts of the hypothalamic periventricular zone.

The ventral division of the MEA (the anterodorsal, anteroventral, and posteroventral parts) is characterized by dense projections to the transverse and interfascicular nuclei of the BST, and to the lateral part of the medial preoptic, anterior hypothalamic, and ventromedial hypothalamic nuclei.

However, dorsal regions of the ventral division provide rather dense inputs to the medial preoptic region and capsule of the ventromedial nucleus, whereas ventral regions of the ventral division preferentially innervate the anterior hypothalamic, dorsomedial, and ventral parts of the ventromedial nuclei.

Functional evidence suggests that circuits associated with dorsal regions of the ventral division may deal with reproductive behavior, whereas circuits associated with ventral regions of the ventral division may deal preferentially with agonistic behavior. 61996 WiIey-Liss, Inc.

Introduction.S: The medial nucleus of the amygdala (MEA) is influenced directly by gonadal steroid hormones (Pfaff and Keiner, 1973; Sar and Stumpf, 1975; Simerly et al., 19901, and integrates chemosensory stimuli relayed by the vomeronasal and main olfactory pathways, as well as by genital somatosensory inputs (Scalia and Winans, 1975; Krettek and Price, 1978b; Lehman and Winans, 1982; Canteras et al., 1992a; Rowe and Erskine, 1993).

Thus, it is not surprising that the MEA plays an important role in both male and female rodent copulatory behavior (Harris and Sachs, 1975; Lehman et al., 1980; Pfaus et al., 1993; Rajendren and Moss, 19931, and apparently in the neuroendocrine events that accompany copulation, such as prolactin and luteinizing hormone surges (Rajendren and Moss, 1993; Rowe and Erskine, 1993; Pfeiffer and Johnston, 1994).

A large body of evidence also suggests that the MEA is involved in social learning processes that modulate agonistic behavior (Luiten et al., 1985; Vochteloo and Koolhaas, 19871, as well as in neural circuits mediating the regulation of aldosterone-induced salt appetite (Schulkin et al., 19891, body weight control (Tubbiola et al., 1989; Levin, 19911, thermoregulation (Frederico et al., 19959, and the neuroendocrine control of growth hormone (Kato et al., 1986) and corticosterone (Dunn and Whitener, 1986; Feldman et al., 1990) secretion.

Current understanding of axonal projections from the MEA that presumably mediate these functions is based mainly on anterograde axonal tracer studies that did not examine possible differential outputs from the various subdivisions of the nucleus (Krettek and Price, 1978a,b; Kevetter and Winans, 1981; Luiten et al., 1985; Caffe et al., 1987).

The MEA is a complex structure that has been divided on cytoarchitectonic grounds (de Olmos et al., 1985) into seemingly clear anteroventral (MEAav), anterodorsal (MEAad), posteroventral (MEApv), and posterodorsal (MEApd) parts.
It is now clear that the several parts of the MEA display unique patterns of gonadal steroid receptor expression.
For example, while androgen receptor mRNA is expressed abundantly throughout the MEA, estrogen receptor mRNA is expressed mainly in the MEApd (Simerly et al., 1990).

Furthermore, neuropeptide synthesis is not uniform throughout the MEA; neurons expressing cholecystokinin, substance P, and angiotensin also tend to be localized almost entirely to specific areas of the MEApd (Simerly and Swanson, 1987; Simerly et al., 1989; Lind and Ganten, 1990).
This chemoarchitectonic evidence lends support to the possibility that different parts of the MEAmay give rise to somewhat different projections.

Recently, Gomez and Newman (1992) examined projections from the hamster MEA with the Phaseolus uuZgaris leucoagglutinin (PHAL) anterograde tracer method and reported different patterns of labeled axons from anterior and posterior injections in the nucleus.
They showed that projections from the MEAav and MEAad considered together are distinct from those arising in the MEApd, although projections from the MEApv were not examined.

In the present study we have conducted, in the rat, a more comprehensive examination of MEA projections with the PHAL method, which is known to yield small injection sites that can be defined precisely on the basis of labeled perikarya.

It is also a very sensitive anterograde tracttracing method that allows visualization of labeled axons, including terminal boutons and boutons-of-passage, with the clarity of Golgi impregnations (Gerfen and Sawchenko, 1984).
Thus, it has been possible to obtain an accurate profile of specific outputs from the anterodorsal, posteroventral, and posterodorsal parts of the nucleus.
Because the anteroventral part is so tiny, PHAL deposits confined entirely within its borders were not obtained, although it was still possible to distinguish some of its characteristic projections.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Twenty adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (240-310 g) received a single injection of PHAL (Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA) into the region of the MEA.

Each animal was anesthetized with tribromoethanol (0.25 gikg b.w., dissolved in 9O:lO saline:ethanol, viv), and a single iontophoretic injection of a 2.5% solution of PHAL in 0.1 M sodium phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4) was made through a stereotaxically positioned glass micropipette (tip diameter 10 pm) by applying a +5 pA current pulsed at 7 second intervals provided by a constant-current source (Midgard Electronics, model CS3), for a period of 15 minutes.
Postinjection survival times for all experiments ranged from 15 to 18 days.
The animals were perfused and the brains were processed according to procedures described in detail elsewhere (Canteras et al., 1992a).

Briefly, each animal was deeply anesthetized with tribromoethanol and perfused transcardially with a solution of 4.0% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M sodium borate buffer at pH 9.5; the brains were removed immediately and postfixed overnight in the same fixative containing 10% sucrose.

Three series of 30 Fm thick frozen frontal sections were cut on a sliding microtome and collected at the following frequencies: one-in-ten through the olfactory bulbs and forebrain rostral to the vascular organ of the lamina terminalis, one-in-four through the hypothalamus and rostral half of the midbrain, and one-in-ten through the caudal midbrain and hindbrain.
Additional sections were collected through the injection site and quick-stained as described in detail elsewhere (see Simerly and Swanson, 1988) to verify the location and size of the PHAL deposit.
One complete series of sections was processed for immunohistochemistry with an antiserum directed against PHAL (Dako Laboratories; 1:1,000 dilution).

The antigen-antibody complex was localized with a variant of the avidinbiotin complex system (ABC; Hsu et al., 19811, using a commercially available kit (ABC Elite kit, Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA).
The sections were mounted on gelatin-coated slides and treated with osmium tetroxide to enhance visibility of the reaction product.
Slides were then dehydrated and coverslipped with DPX.
An adjacent series was always stained with thionin to serve as a reference series for cytoarchitectonic purposes.
Sections were examined with a Leitz Laborlux D microscope (brightand dark-field illumination).
PHAL-labeled cells in the injection sites, and the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers, were plotted with the aid of a camera lucida on maps prepared from adjacent Nissl-stained sections.
For illustration, the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers was transferred onto a series of standard rat brain drawings (Swanson, 1992).

In transposing our results onto standard drawings, as a first step we tried to match as closely as possible the actual section to be represented with the corresponding section (or sections) in the atlas (Swanson, 1992), based on a careful observation of cytoarchitectonic features.

To achieve the most accurate representation, once the correct standard section was chosen for a given pathway or terminal field, in addition to the maps prepared with the aid of a camera lucida, constant observation of the actual material was accomplished with a Leitz Laborlux D microscope while plotting the distribution of anterogradely labeled fibers onto the standard drawing, nucleus by nucleus.
Unless otherwise indicated, parcellation of the rat brain follows Swanson (1992).
Descriptions of axonal morphology at the light microscopic level are those commonly used in conjunction with Golgi-impregnated material, and are discussed in Risold et al. (1994).

In brief, it is highly probable that terminal boutons and boutons-of-passage (together referred to as terminals) form synapses, whereas the significance of varicosities along axons is much less clear and must be established at the ultrastructural level.

Results.S: RESULTS
Parcellation
Before describing the experimental results it is important to discuss our interpretation of the MEA parcellation advanced by De Olmos et al. (1985).
Based on cytoarchitecture they subdivided the nucleus into four parts: anterodorsal, anteroventral, posterodorsal, and posteroventral (Figs. 1, 2).
Briefly, the entire MEA displays a molecular layer dominated by inputs from various parts of the accessory and main olfactory systems reviewed below.
The MEAad is the largest component, extending throughout the rostral two thirds of the amygdala, and merging rostrally with the anterior amygdaloid area and caudally with the MEApd.
It contains a heterogeneous population of small to mediumsized neurons (Figs. 1A,B, 2A,B).
Ventral to the rostral half of the MEAad, a small, wellldefined, cell-dense region that corresponds to MEAav may be observed in Nissl preparations (Figs. lA, 2A).
The MEApv lies ventrally in the caudal third of the MEA and is also a clearly outlined region; it contains a relatively homogeneous population of mediumsized neurons (Figs. lC,D, 2C,D).
Finally, the MEApd (Figs. 1C,D, 2C,D) is shaped roughly like an elongated triangle with a ventral base.

It lies dorsally in the caudal third of the MEA and presents a characteristic cytoarchitectonic organization: cell-dense regions lie superficially and deep, separated by a relatively cell-sparse intermediate region (labeled a, c, and b, respectively, in Swanson, 1992).
Injection sites
The following description of projections is based on 20 PHAL injections where labeled neurons were confined almost entirely to the MEA.
Of these, five injections were almost entirely limited to the MEAad, three to the MEApv, and three to the MEApd.
The appearance and location of PHAL-labeled cells for representative injections localized primarily to these three parts of the nucleus are shown in Figure 3B,B , 3C,C , and 3D,D .
In addition, as illustrated in Figure 3A,A , one injection was centered in the MEAav, with a significant number of labeled cells in the MEAad.

The remaining eight experiments with PHAL injections confined to the MEA were centered in the anterodorsal part, but also included a number of PHAL-labeled neurons in the posterodorsal (four experiments), posteroventral (one experiment), or anteroventral (three experiments) parts of the nucleus.
Projections from the medial nucleus of the amygdala
Regardless of the precise location of PHAL injection sites in the MEA, labeled axons followed the same basic routes.
A detailed account of these pathways will be given in the description of MEAad outputs.

What little could be gleaned about the projections of the MEAav is described with those of the MEAad because all injections centered in the former spread to include a significant extent of the latter.
Projections from the MEAad

TTE.S: All five experiments with a PHAL injection site confined almost entirely to the MEAad labeled a very similar pattern of axons.
Experiment MEA number 2 was chosen as a prototype to illustrate (Figs. 3B,B , 4) because the injection labeled the most extensive population of MEAad neurons.
Zntraamygdalar terminal fields.
A remarkable plexus of anterogradely labeled axons was found to extend through much of the amygdala (Fig. 41-Q).

However, before describing these intraamygdalar pathways, it is important to note that in all experiments with a PHAL injection restricted to the MEAad, many labeled boutons were observed throughout all parts of the MEA itself, although the density was clearly less in the MEApd(Fig. 4J-0).

Within the amygdala, the MEAad provides especially dense inputs to the anterior amygdaloid area, bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract, central nucleus, anterior and posterior parts of the basomedial nucleus, anterior cortical nucleus, and deep layers of the piriform-amygdaloid area, whereas the posterior cortical nucleus, posterior nucleus, and lateral nucleus contained somewhat less anterograde labeling (Fig. 41-Q).

In the central nucleus, axons from the MEAad were most dense in the capsular part (especially caudally), were moderately dense in the medial part, and clearly tend to avoid the lateral part (Fig. 4J-N).
Curiously, unlike adjacent amygdalar regions, the anterior and posterior parts of the basolateral nucleus receive only a very sparse input from the MEAad (Fig. 4J-P).
Local cortical projections.

One group of fibers from the MEAad that courses through the amygdala extends both laterally toward the piriform area and endopiriform nucleus (Fig. 41-P) and caudally toward the postpiriform transition area (area TR) and hippocampal formation (Fig. 4Q-S).
The piriform area and endopiriform nucleus contain a moderate number of anterogradely labeled fibers that give rise to boutons.
Labeled fibers are found throughout most of the piriform area, but are especially prominent caudally and medially, and in layer 3 (Fig. 4C-P).
Some fibers continue toward the agranular insular area and claustrum, which receive a relatively sparse input from the MEAad (Fig. 4D-M).
A small number of axons coursing through the piriform area also extend rostrally through the lateral olfactory tract to end in the accessory olfactory bulb mitral cell layer (Fig. 4A-E).

In the hippocampal formation, the lateral entorhinal area (all layers) receives a substantial projection from the MEAad, while a smaller number of labeled axons were also observed throughout the ventral subiculum and adjacent ventral parts of field CA1 (Fig. 4Q-S); an even smaller number of labeled axons were found reliably in the medial entorhinal area and parasubiculum (Fig. 4R-S).

Finally, another group of labeled axons from the MEAad extends rostral to the amygdala, where they appear to innervate primarily the fundus of the striatum and layer 3 of the olfactory tubercle (Fig. 4E-I).
The stria terminalis and ansa peduncularis.
The vast majority of MEAad axons that leave the amygdala enter the ansa peduncularis or stria terminalis before innervating a number of telencephalic and diencephalic sites.

An especially large number of fibers course through the ansa peduncularis (in the so-called ventral amygdalofugal pathway), where they form two distinct bundles coursing a) through the substantia innominata or b) directly to and through the lateral hypothalamic area (Fig. 41-L).
At caudal levels of the BST, most fibers coursing through the substantia innominata appear to merge with axons coursing through the stria terminalis.
Together, they innervate caudal regions of the BST, and some of them probably continue ventrally toward the hypothalamus, as described below (Fig. 41).
Labeled fibers in the substantia innominata are usually poorly branched, although they display a significant number of boutons.
At caudal levels they are concentrated ventromedially, but as they approach the BST they fill much of the substantia innominata (Fig. 41-K).
Rostral to this level, some fibers with boutons continue through rostral parts of t.he substantia innominata (Fig. 4D-H).
Septa1 projections.
Fibers in the stria terminalis initially provide a dense input to the septal region, including the BST (see above).
In the posterior division of the BST, the transverse and interfascicular nuclei are filled with a dense plexus of fibers, whereas the principal nucleus receives a rather sparse input (Fig. 41).

In the anterior division of the BST, the MEAad supplies dense inputs to the anterodorsal and anteroventral areas, whereas only caudal zones of the anterolateral area appear to receive a significant number of fibers and boutons (Fig. 4F-H).

Fibers in the stria terminalis also provide a rather dense input to the intermediate and ventral parts of the lateral septal nucleus, as well as very sparse projections to the dorsal part of the lateral, septofimbrial, and medial septal nuclei (Fig. 4D-H).
From the septal region, a few labeled axons extend into and innervate caudalmost parts of the nucleus accumbens (Fig. 4D-E).

Axons from the MEAad in the ansa peduncularis also extend rostrally through the substantia innominata (mentioned above) and ventral to the nucleus of the diagonal band (Fig. 4E-H), and then merge at the level of the nucleus accumbens with axons coursing through the septal region (Fig. 4D).

Labeled fibers running ventral to the nucleus of the diagonal bandgenerate many boutons near the ventromedial surface of the brain (just superficial to neuronal cell bodies in the nucleus of the diagonal band; Fig. 4E-H) .
Prefrontal cortex and accessory olfactory bulb.
Rostral to the nucleus accumbens, axons from the MEAad innervate the medial prefrontal cortex, taenia tecta, anterior olfactory nucleus, and accessory olfactory bulb mitral cell layer (Fig. 4A-C).

Specifically, a few labeled axons were seen in the prelimbic and infralimbic areas of the prefrontal region (Fig. 4 0 , and some fibers extend rostrally through the anterior olfactory nucleus and taenia tecta, where they generate a relatively small number of boutons (Fig. 4B,C).
Some or all of these fibers continue on to provide a relatively dense input to the accessory olfactory bulb mitral cell layer (Fig. 4A).
As mentioned above, a few axons from the MEAad also reach the accessory olfactory bulb mitral cell layer by coursing directly through the lateral olfactory tract.
Hypothalamic projections.

Axons from the MEAad innervate a number of hypothalamic sites, particularly in the medial zone, although it was not possible to determine with certainty the relative contributions of fibers in the stria terminalis and ansa peduncularis to particular terminal fields because of the way these two pathways converge at the level of the septal region (see above).
At preoptic levels, undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area and the lateral part of the medial preoptic nucleus contain a remarkable number of labeled fibers and boutons (Fig. 4H,I).

In contrast, many fewer labeled axons and boutons were observed in more rostral parts of the medial preoptic area, and these fibers clearly tend to avoid the anteroventral periventricular nucleus (Fig. 4G).
The lateral preoptic area contains only sparse labeled axons with the morphological features of fibers-of-passage (few if any boutons, and only occasional varicosities; Fig. 4G,H).

At anterior hypothalamic levels, most labeled fibers also distribute within the medial zone, where they form particularly dense terminal fields in dorsal zones of the central part of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, in adjacent regions surrounding the paraventricular nucleus (including the subparaventricular zone), and in the retrochiasmatic area (Fig. 4J-L).

In sharp contrast, the periventricular zone at this level contains only a few anterogradely labeled fibers, which appear to be more numerous in the anterior parvicellular part of the paraventricular nucleus (Fig. 4J-L).

At tuberal levels, axons from the MEAad form a dense terminal field in the capsule of the ventromedial nucleus, whereas the nucleus itself contains relatively fewer labeled axons and boutons (see Figs. 4L-0, 7B).

However, in experiments with PHAL injection sites labeling a substantial population of neurons in the anteroventral part of the MEA, a very dense plexus of labeled axons was seen within the ventromedial nucleus itself (particularly in the central and dorsomedial parts; see Fig. 7A).
In contrast, the dorsomedial nucleus receives few axons from the MEAad (Fig. 4N,O).

The MEAad also provides substantial inputs to a region (the tuberal nucleus; see Canteras et al., '94) immediately lateral to ventral parts of the ventromedial nucleus (Fig. 4M-0), and to a region of the lateral hypothalamic area immediately adjacent to the cerebral peduncle (Fig. 40,P).
Finally, labeled fibers and boutons at the tuberal level were also found reliably in the intermediate periventricular nucleus and lateral regions of the arcuate nucleus (Fig. 4L-0).

Axons from the MEAad continue on to the rnarnmillary level, where they provide dense inputs to the posterior periventricular nucleus, ventral premammillary nucleus, and ventral regions of the posterior nucleus; and more sparse inputs to the fiber capsule around superficial parts of the medial mammillary nucleus (Fig. 4P-R), and both parts of the supramammillary nucleus (Fig. 4Q).
Thalamic projections.
Some labeled axons leave dorsal parts of the hypothalamus to enter the thalamus, whereas a few others leave the stria terminalis to enter the thalamus via the stria medullaris.
In the ventral thalamus, MEAad inputs, which are sparse, appear confined mostly to rostral parts of the zona incerta (Fig. 4L-N).

In contrast, the dorsal thalamus contains a particularly dense plexus of labeled fibers in ventral regions of the nucleus reuniens, and a substantial projection to the paraventricular nucleus and medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus (Fig. 41-PI.
Very sparse anterograde labeling was also observed in the parataenial nucleus, lateral habenula, and subparafascicular nucleus (Fig. 41-P).
Brainstem projections.

A few axons coursing through the posterior hypothalamic nucleus extend caudally into periependymal regions of the periaqueductal gray (Fig. 4Q-S), provide a sparse input to the dorsal raphe nucleus, and continue as far caudal as the pontine central gray (not illustrated).

A few axons coursing through the lateral hypothalamic area extend caudally into the midbrain, where they provide a sparse input to the ventral tegmental area, and the interfascicular, rostral linear, and central linear raphe nuclei (Fig. 4R-S).
Contralateral projections.

It is important to note that projections from the MEAad are mostly ipsilateral, although a very small number of axons cross the midline in the anterior commissure, supraoptic commissures, and supramammillary decussation.

Occasional labeled fibers were observed on the contralateral side only in those regions with a very dense ipsilateral projection, including the accessory olfactory bulb mitral cell layer, lateral septal nucleus, BST, medial preoptic area, ventromedial nucleus, ventral premammillary nucleus, and nucleus reuniens.
Virtually no anterograde labeling was observed in the contralateral amygdala.

Results.S: Projections from the MEApv

TTE.S: In three experiments the PHAL deposit was virtually confined to the MEApv, and each displayed a similar pattern of anterograde labeling.
Experiment MEApv number 2 was chosen as a prototype to illustrate our results (Figs. 3C,C , 5).
Zntraamygdar terminal fields.

The MEApv projects extensively within the amygdala, with a pattern resembling in may ways that described for the MEAad. 1) Axons and terminals were found throughout the rest of the MEA, although they are considerably more dense in the MEAad and MEAav than in the MEApd (Fig. 5G-L). 2) Many labeled terminals were observed in the anterior amygdaloid area, bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract, anterior and posterior parts of the basomedial nucleus, piriformamygdaloid area, anterior and posterior cortical nuclei, and posterior nucleus (Fig. 5F-N). 3) As with the MEAad, the MEApv provides a moderate input to the lateral amygdaloid nucleus, where labeled fibers tended to be concentrated ventrally (Fig. 5K-M), and 4), in contrast to the MEAad, the MEApv innervates mainly ventral regions of the capsular central nucleus, and the medial central nucleus contains only a few labeled terminals (Fig. 5G-K).
Local cortical projections.

As with the MEAad, labeled axons from the MEApv course through the amygdala to the piriform area and endopiriform nucleus (Fig. 5B-M), and to the postpiriform transition area (area TR) and hippocampal formation (Fig. 5N-P).
Some axons in the piriform area extend to the agranular insular area and claustrum (Fig. 5B-J).

As with the MEAad, the MEApv contributes moderate inputs to the lateral entorhinal area, and very sparse inputs to the ventral subiculum, adjacent ventral parts of field CA1, parasubiculum, and medial entorhinal area (Fig. 5N-P).
In contrast to the MEAad, however, only a few axons from the MEApv extend rostral to the amygdala into the striatal fundus and olfactory tubercle (Fig. 5B-F).
The stria terminalis and ansa peduncularis.
Most descending axons of neurons in the MEApv follow the stria terminalis and ansa peduncularis (Fig. 5F-L).

However, as compared to the MEAad, many fewer axons course through the ventral route, where their course through and to the substantia innominata is essentially the same as that described for the MEAad (Fig. 5F-I).

Axons from the MEApv in these two pathways innervate basically the same general regions of the telencephalon and diencephalon as axons from the MEAad, although typically they generate a topographically distinct terminal field within a particular region.
Septalprojections.

The MEApv provides a dense projection to the posterior division of the BST, where (as with the MEAad) labeled axons tend to avoid the principal nucleus, and instead provide a strikingly dense input to the interfascicular and transverse nuclei (Fig. 5F).

On the other hand, projections to the anterior division of the BST differ somewhat for the MEAad and MEApv, with the latter providing a dense input to the anterodorsal, a sparse input to the anteroventral, and a very sparse input to the anterolateral areas (Fig. 5C-El.
Furthermore, the MEApv provides only a sparse input to the intermediate and ventral parts of the lateral septal nucleus (Fig. 5B-E).
Finally, some axons from the MEApv were observed extending rostral to the septal region, and they appear to end in the infralimbic and prelimbic areas (Fig. 5A).
Importantly, and in contrast to the MEAad, no labeled axons from the MEApv could be followed to any part of the olfactory bulb.
Hypothalamic projections.
The pattern of hypothalamic projections observed in experiments with PHAL deposits restricted to the MEApv was distinct in many ways from that described for the MEAad.

At the preoptic level, the MEApv, like the MEAad, provides a rather dense input to the caudal pole of the medial preoptic nucleus (Fig. 5F), whereas at more rostral levels, the MEApv (unlike the MEAad) provides relatively few axons and terminals throughout undifferentiated parts of the medial preoptic area and the lateral and medial parts of the medial preoptic nucleus (Fig. 5C-E).

At the anterior hypothalamic leuel, the MEApv provides a denser projection than the MEAad to the medial zone, where many labeled terminalswere seen in the region surrounding the suprachiasmatic nucleus; retrochiasmatic area; rostral pole, central, and posterior parts of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus; and regions near the periventricular zone, including the (Fig. 5F-I).
At the tuberal level, the MEApv provides an impressive plexus of labeled fibers to the capsule of the ventromedial nucleus, and to the dorsomedial and central parts of the nucleus itself.
This projection tends to avoid the ventrolatera1 part of the ventromedial nucleus, whereas the adjacent tuberal nucleus receives a substantial input (see Figs. 51-L, 7C).

Interestingly, the dense plexus of fibers in the capsule of the ventromedial nucleus invades the periventricular zone and appears to provide a very dense input to the intermediate periventricular nucleus, although only a few axons extend ventrally into the arcuate nucleus (Fig. 51-L).
A few labeled axons from the MEApv also appear to end in the dorsomedial nucleus (Fig. 5K-L).
In addition, unlike the MEAad, the MEApv projects only sparsely to the region of the lateral hypothalamic area adjacent to the cerebral peduncle (Fig. 5L-M).

At the mammillary level, just caudal to the ventromedial nucleus, a relatively dense plexus of fibers is found in the ventral premammillary nucleus and ventral regions of the posterior nucleus, whereas only a few labeled axons are observed in the posterior periventricular nucleus (Fig. 5M).
A small number of fibers also appear to innervate the supramammillary nucleus and fiber capsule around the medial mammillary nucleus (Fig. 5N,O).
Thalamic projections.
As with the MEAad, some fibers coursing through the hypothalamus from the MEApv extend dorsally into thalamus.

In the ventral thalamus only occasional fibers were observed in rostral parts of the zona incerta (Fig. 5I-K), whereas in the dorsal thalamus, a rostroventral zone of the nucleus reuniens receives a moderate input from the MEApv, although it is far less dense than that described for the MEAad (Fig. 5G,H).
In contrast to the MEAad, the MEApv provides only a few axons to the paraventricular nucleus, and no anterograde labeling was found in the mediodorsal nucleus (Fig. 5F-M).
Brainstem projections.
A small group of fibersextends from the posterior hypothalamic nucleus into the periaqueductal gray (Fig. 5N,O).
At least a few such fibers were observed throughout its rostrocaudal extent, as well as in the dorsal nucleus of the raphe (not illustrated).
In contrast to the MEAad, the MEApv provides only an occasional fiber the ventral tegmental area, and the nearby interfascicular, rostral linear, and central linear nuclei of the raphe (Fig. 50.P).
Contralateral projections.

As with the MEAad, the MEApv projects lightly to the contralateral side, basically to those regions with a very dense ipsilateral projection, including the BST, anterior hypothalamic nucleus, ventromedial nucleus, ventral premammillary nucleus, and posterior hypothalamic nucleus.
These fibers also cross the midline through the anterior commissure, supraoptic commissures, and supramammillary decussation.
However, they do not appear to innervate the contralateral amygdala to any significant extent.

Results.S: Projections from the MEApd

TTE.S: Three experiments contained a PHAL deposit that was confined to the MEApd and each displayed a similar pattern of anterogradely labeled fibers; experiment MEApd number 3 was chosen as a prototype for illustration (Figs. 3D,D' and 6).
Zntraamygdalar terminal fields.
From the injection site, anterogradely labeled fibers extend throughout other parts of the MEA (Fig. 6H-L).

Elsewhere in the amygdala, there is a dense projection to the posterior cortical nucleus that ends primarily in the molecular layer of the medial part, and layers 1 and 2 in caudal regions of the lateral part (Fig. 6L-N), and a moderate projection to the posterior nucleus (Fig. 6GM).

Unlike other parts of the MEA, the MEApd sends very few axons to the anterior amygdaloid area, bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract, anterior and posterior basomedial nucleus, deep layers of the posterior cortical nucleus, and piriform-amygdaloid area (Fig. 6F-N).
A moderate number of fibers with boutons were observed ventromedially in the capsular central nucleus, and only a few labeled axons were observed in the medial part of the nucleus.
Local cortical projections.

As with other parts of the MEA, the ME-4pd sends a group of fibers through the amygdala to the postpiriform transition area and hippocampal formation (Fig. 6N-P), although few labeled axons could be traced to the piriform area and endopiriform nucleus (Fig. 6F-M).

The distribution of labeled axons within the hippocampal formation is similar to that described for other parts of the MEA: they are distributed mainly within the lateral part of the entorhinal area, although a few labeled terminals were also found in the medial part of the entorhinal area, ventral subiculum, and adjacent ventral parts of field CA1 (Fig. 6N-P).
The stria terminalis and ansa peduncularis.
The stria terminalis represents by far the major pathway followed by descending projections from the MEApd.
A few axons leave the amygdala via the ansa peduncularis, and their course through (and to) the substantia innominata is similar to that for other parts of the MEA.

Axons from the MEApd in the stria terminalis appear to end in a number of telencephalic and diencephalic sites, including the septal region, infralimbic area of the prefrontal cortex, and several hypothalamic nuclei, although their distribution pattern is quite distinct from that outlined for other parts of the MEA.
Septa1 and prefrontal inputs.

In the posterior division of the BST, a very dense plexus of terminals was observed in the principal nucleus, rather than the interfascicular and transverse nuclei, which appear to receive very few axons (Fig. 6F).

In the anterior division of the BST, the anterodorsal area contains a relatively large number of terminals, whereas only a few axons were observed in the anteroventral and anterolateral areas (Fig. 6C-E).
Few labeled axons from MEApd injections reach the lateral septal nucleus, where they generate a small number of terminals in the ventral and intermediate parts (Fig. 6B-E).
In addition, a few labeled axons extend rostrally toward the prefrontal region, where they end in the infralimbic area (Fig. 6A), the most rostra1 target of the MEApd.
Hypothalamic projections.
At the preoptic level, axons from the MEApd generate a strikingly dense input to the anteroventral periventricular and medial preoptic nuclei (Fig. 6C-F).
This is an important feature because the anteroventral periventricular nucleus receives very sparse inputs from other parts of the MEA.

Furthermore, projections from the MEApd to the medial and central parts of the medial preoptic nucleus are clearly more dense than in the lateral part (except for the caudal pole of the medial preoptic nucleus) (Fig. 6E), whereas the opposite was seen in all the experiments with injection sites that did not involve the MEApd.
At the anterior hypothalamic level, many labeled fibers extend caudally from the preoptic level through the anterior hypothalamic nucleus.
Most of these axons present widely spaced varicosities and very few boutons, thus resembling fibers-of-passage (Fig. 6G-I).

At the tuberal level, PHAL-containing axons arriving by way of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus are found mainly in the capsule surrounding the central and ventrolateral parts of the ventromedial nucleus and immediately adjacent regions of the tuberal nucleus (Figs. 6J-L, 7D).
Curiously, these labeled axons are also very poorly branched and appear to generate relatively few boutons (Figs. 6J-L, 7D).
Some axons at this level extend into the periventricular zone, where they appear to innervate lightly the intermediate periventricular and arcuate nuclei (Fig. 61-L).

At the mammillary level, just caudal to the ventromedial nucleus, fibers descending through the medial zone form a massive terminal field in the ventral premammillary nucleus and adjacent ventral regions of the posterior nucleus (Fig. 6M).

Some labeled axons extend caudally into the mammillary body, where they end in the fiber capsule around caudal regions of the medial mammillary nucleus, and in the supramammillary nucleus (Fig. 6N,O).
Very few axons from the MEApd extend into the thalamus (Fig. 6F-M) and periaqueductal gray (Fig. 6N-PI.
Contralateral projections.
As with other parts of the MEA, only a few axons from the MEApd could be traced to the contralateral side of the brain through the three pathways described above.
Contralateral fibers are distributed to basically those parts of the septum and hypothalamus with a dense ipsilateral terminal field.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The present results confirm and extend earlier views about how the very complex axonal projections from the MEA are organized, and thus hopefully provide a relatively accurate description of pathways and terminal fields arising in anterodorsal, posteroventral, and posterodorsal parts of the nucleus.
At least certain characteristic projections from the anteroventral part of the nucleus were also elucidated, although its very small volume prevented definitive analysis.
Overall, our results provide hodological support for the cytoarchitectonic parcellation of the MEA proposed by De Olmos et al. (1985).
Projections from the medial nucleus of the amygdala

In all experiments with a PHAL deposit confined to the MEA, labeled axons followed the same basic pathways (Fig. 8), regardless of differences observed in the distribution pattern of specific terminal fields.
The output of the MEA is mostly ipsilateral, with a few axons crossing the midline through the anterior commissure, supraoptic commissures, and supramammillary decussation.

Axons from the MEA initially generate dense terminal fields in several parts of the amygdala, and some fibers extend laterally to the piriform area and associated endopiriform nucleus, caudally to the postpiriform transition area and hippocampal formation, or rostrally to the striatal fundus, olfactory tubercle, and accessory olfactory bulb.
Most extraamygdalar axons from the MEA join the ansa peduncularis (ventral amygdalofugal component) or stria terminalis to end in a number of telencephalic and diencephalic sites.

The MEAad, and to a lesser extent the MEApv, contribute an many fibers to the ansa peduncularis, whereas only a few axons arising in the MEApd, a cell group that ascends with the stria terminalis along the medial edge of the tip of the temporal horn of the lateral ventricle (see plate 30 in Swanson, 19921, join this pathway to and through the substantia innominata.

As in the hamster (Gomez and Newman, 19921, our results indicate that MEA outputs tend to course through medial regions of the stria terminalis, with axons from the MEAad and MEApv tending to lie ventral to those from the MEApd.
Intraamygdalar and olfactory projections.
We confirm that the MEA establishes massive intraamygdalar connections, and suggest that each part of the nucleus generates a distinct pattern of terminal fields.

Our results also confirm dense intrinsic connections within the MEA itself (Nishizuka and Arai, 1983; Gomez and Newman, 1992); and indicate specifically that the MEAad, MEApv, and possibly MEAav, are heavily interconnected, unlike the MEApd, which establishes much lighter interconnections with the rest of the nucleus.
This is one of many indications that the MEA consists essentially of ventral and dorsal divisions, with the MEAad, av, and pv included in the former, and the MEApd constituting the latter.

This view of two primary divisions is strengthened by evidence that projection patterns from the MEAad and MEApv to other parts of the amygdala are similar but differ markedly from that observed for the MEApd.

The MEAad and MEApv generate substantial intraamygdalar terminal fields in structures related particularly to the vomeronasal system (medial posterior cortical nucleus, posterior nucleus, and bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract); the main olfactory bulb (anterior amygdaloid area, anterior cortical nucleus, piriform-amygdaloid area, and lateral posterior cortical nucleusj; and the basolateral complex (basomedial and lateral nuclei).

In contrast, substantial projections from the MEApd are restricted to the posteromedial cortical and posterior nuclei (accessory system) and the posterolateral cortical nucleus (main system), and only a light input to the basomedial nucleus is found.
One difference is that medial and capsular parts of the central nucleus clearly receive larger inputs from the MEAad than from the MEApv.
The MEApd projects lightly to these parts of the central nucleus, and no part of the MEA sends more than a few axons to the lateral central nucleus.

Projections from the MEA to the posterior cortical, basomedial, and anterior cortical nuclei were inferred from autoradiographic studies (Krettek and Price, 1978b), although local connections are difficult to establish autoradiographically.
The intraamygdalar MEA projections identified here are, with two exceptions, similar to those described with PHAL in the hamster (Gomez and Newman, 1992).
However, they reported a projection to layers 2 and 3 of the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract, which was notably free of anterograde labeling here.
Furthermore, they did not describe a projection from the MEA to the lateral nucleus of the amygdala, although it had been suggested in the rat by Ottersen ( 1982) using horseradish peroxidase.
These discrepancies may reflect species differences.

The MEA receives a massive input from the accessory olfactory bulb, and possibly a very restricted input from the main olfactory bulb to the rostral tip of the MEAad (Scalia and Winans, 1975; Lehman and Winans, 1982).
However, main olfactory information reaches most of the nucleus via intraamygdalar projections from the anterior cortical nucleus (Ottersen, 1982; G.
Petrovich and L.W.

Swanson, unpublished observations with PHAL), lateral posterior cortical nucleus (Canteras et al., 1992a), and piriformamygdaloid area (Ottersen, 19821, and possibly from the endopiriform nucleus (Krettek and Price, 1978b) and piriform area (Luskin and Price, 1983).

Thus, the MEA as a whole may be viewed as an important site for the integration of olfactory information from the accessory system with that from the main system, and for sending this information to other parts of the amygdala, some of which also process information from the main and/or accessory olfactory bulbs.
The MEA also projects back to a number of extraamygdalar parts of the olfactory system and is thus in an even stronger position to modulate the central flow of olfactory information.
The MEA projects directly to the accessory olfactory bulb i:De Olmos et al., 19781, and we have demonstrated specifically that the MEAad innervates its projection cell layer.

The medial posterior cortical nucleus (which receives an input from most or all parts of the MEA) also generates a robust projection back to the accessory olfactory bulb, although it appears to be directed mainly to the granular layer (Canteras et al., 1992a).

Thus, the MEA and medial posterior cortical nucleus, which both receive inputs from the accessory olfactory bulb, project back to different cell types in the accessory olfactory bulb, and presumably influence differentially the central flow of vomeronasal information.
Gomez and Newman (1992) described a major projection from the hamster MEA to the anterior olfactory nucleus, whereas our material suggests that this projection is sparse in the rat.

Our results also confirm evidence (Caffe et al., 1987; Gomez and Newman, 1992) for MEA projections to the endopiriform nucleus and cortical areas receiving direct inputs from the main olfactory bulb (olfactory tubercle; piriform, piriform-amygdaloid, postpiriform transition, lateral entorhinal areas).
All of these cortical areas, and the endopiriform nucleus, receive substantial inputs from the MEAad and MEApv, but sparse inputs from the MEApd, in the rat.
Hippocampal inputs.

Aside from the lateral entorhinal area input just mentioned, the MEA projects to other parts of the hippocampal formation, including the medial entorhinal area, parasubiculum, and especially ventral subiculumi ventral field CA1.
MEA inputs to the ventral subiculumi field CA1 was described by Caffe et al. (19871, who suggested that it may contain vasopressin.

The entorhinal area constitutes the starting point of the hippocampal trisynaptic circuit, and field CA1 and the subiculum are on the output side of this circuit, which is thought to play an important role in short-term episodic memory (see Swanson et al., 1987).
Projections to the septum.

A projection from the MEA to the BST is known (Krettek and Price, 1978a; De Olmos et al., 1985; Price et al., 19871, and our results on projections from the MEA to the BST and substantia innominata largely confirm those of Gomez and Newman (1992) in the hamster.
It appears that the MEA participates in two relatively distinct circuits.
Our results indicate that the MEAad and MEApv provide similar BST projections, which differ markedly from those of the MEApd.
In the posterior BST, the MEAad and MEApv generate dense terminal fields in the interfascicular and transverse nuclei, whereas the MEApd projects densely to the principal nucleus.

In the anterior division, all parts of the MEA generate a dense terminal field in the anterodorsal area, whereas only the MEAad innervates significantly the anteroventral area and caudal anterolateral area.

The principal nucleus of the BST also receives a dense input from the posterior amygdalar nucleus, and both cell groups innervate densely the MEApd, and hypothalamic regions innervated by the MEApd (Simerly et al., 1989; Canteras et al., 1992a).

Thus, the MEApd, posterior nucleus of the amygdala, and principal nucleus of the BST constitute an interconnected group of basal telencephalic nuclei innervating essentially the same constellation of hypothalamic nuclei.
In contrast, the MEAad and MEApv are massively interconnected, and both densely innervate the interfascicular and transverse nuclei of the BST.

In agreement with retrograde tracer results (Grove, 1988a), our observations indicate that the MEAad, and to a lesser extent the MEApv and MEApd, provide a dense input to neurons in the substantia innominata along the course of the ventral amygdalofugal pathway.

Caudal parts of the ventral substantia innominata, and parts of the BST observed here to receive dense inputs from the MEAad and MEApv, may project to the MEA (Swanson and Cowan, 1979; Grove, 1988a,b), although the distribution of such fibers in the MEA is unclear.

Thus, current evidence indicates that the MEAad and MEApv (and possibly the MEAav), along with parts of the BST densely innervated by these parts of the MEA (interfascicular and transverse nuclei) and certain regions of the caudal substantia innominata, are highly interrelated, forming part of a circuit distinct from that associated with the MEApd.

Because the MEAad projects heavily to the central nucleus of the amygdala, it is interesting that the MEAad also projects to caudal regions of the anterolateral part of the BST, which also receives a dense input from the central nucleus (Krettek and Price, 1978a; Sun et al., 1991).
We confirmed (Caffe et al., 1987; Gomez and Newman, 1992) a projection from the MEA to the lateral septal nucleus, although it is markedly sparser than that to the BST.
This projection is distributed mainly to the intermediate and ventral parts of the lateral septal nucleus, and appears to arise mainly within the MEAad.
Some of these fibers may be vasopressinergic (Caffe et al., 1987).
Inputs to the ventral striatum.

Rostral to the septum, the striatal fundus and olfactory tubercle polymorphic layer receive substantial inputs from the MEAad, and it also projects lightly to the caudal shell of the nucleus accumbens (Zahm and Brog, 1992).

Projections from the rostral MEA to the striatal fundus and olfactory tubercle have been seen in the hamster by Gomez and Newman (1992), who reported a dense projection to the shell of the nucleus accumbens.
A sparse projection in the rat is supported by a few retrogradely labeled cells in the rat MEA after fluorogold injections in the shell region (Brog et al., 1993).

In addition to a direct projection to the ventral striatum, information processed in the MEA may be conveyed to the striatum indirectly via a projection to the basomedial nucleus of the amygdala, which provides a major input to the striatum (Kelley et al., 1982; Brog et al., 1993).
Projections to the hypothalamus.
Different parts of the MEA provide distinct inputs to the hypothalamus, confirming and extending work in the hamster (Gomez and Newman, 1992).
Overall, the MEA generates dense inputs to the entire extent of the hypothalamic medial zone.

A projection from the MEA to medial parts of thepreoptic region is well established (Keveter and Winans, 1981; Berk and Finkelstein, 1981; Simerly and Swanson, 1986; Caffe et al., 1987; Maragos et al., 1989; Simerly et al., 1989; Gomez and Newman, 1992).

Our results indicate that the caudal pole of the medial preoptic nucleus (mainly the caudal end of the lateral part of the nucleus) receives a dense input from all parts of the MEA, although more rostrally, different parts of the MEA generate distinct projections within this general area.

In the rostral 2/3 of the preoptic region the MEAad projects very densely to undifferentiated zones of the medial preoptic area and the lateral medial preoptic nucleus, in contrast to the MEApd, which innervates densely the central and medial parts of the medial preoptic nucleus, and the anteroventral periventricular nucleus; remarkably, fibers arising in other parts of the MEA clearly avoid the latter.

A differential pattern of inputs to medial parts of the hamster preoptic region from anterior and posterodorsal parts of the MEA was reported by Gomez and Newman (1992), although their cytoarchitectonic parcellation of the preoptic region differs from ours.

We also observed that the MEApv, which was not investigated specifically by Gomez and Newman (1992), projects densely to the caudal pole of the medial preoptic nucleus, but unlike other parts of the MEA supplies many fewer axons to rostral levels of the medial preoptic region.

At the anterior hypothalamic level, the MEApv supplies dense inputs to the rostral pole, central, and posterior parts of the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, retrochiasmatic area, perisuprachiasmatic region, and subparaventricular zone.
A similar but sparser projection to the anterior hypothalamic level was also observed from the MEAad, in contrast to the MEApd, which supplied a modest number of terminals to this hypothalamic level.
The projection from the MEA to the anterior hypothalamic level has not been examined with retrograde axonal tracers, although similar results were reported by Gomez and Newman (1992).

At tuberal levels, it is clear that the MEA projects topographically to the ventromedial and adjacent tuberal nuclei (Krettek and Price, 1978a; Post and Mai, 1980; Berk and Finkelstein, 1981; Kevetter and Winans, 1981; Kita and Oomura, 1982; Zaborszky, 1982; Luiten et al., 1983; Ono et al., 1985; Luiten et al., 1985; Caffe et al., 1987; Fahrbach et al., 1989; Simerly et al., 1989; Gomez and Newman, 1992).

Earlier work in the rat (Krettek and Price, 1978a; Post and Mai, 1980) suggested that the MEA projects preferentially to the cellular core of the ventromedial nucleus, although injection sites in these studies did not label specific parts of the MEA.

Gomez and Newman (1992) later emphasized that anterior regions of the hamster MEA, including the MEAav and MEAad, innervate preferentially the core of the ventromedial nucleus, whereas the MEApd innervates primarily the surrounding capsule.

Our results indicate that the rat MEAad projects more densely to the capsule than to the core, and the MEAav provides especially dense inputs to the core of the nucleus (especially ventrally and dorsomedially).
The MEApv projects massively to both core and capsule, although MEApv fibers clearly tend to avoid the ventrolateral part of the nucleus.

In contrast to all the other parts of the MEA, the MEApd projects only sparsely to the VMH, where labeled axons were observed mainly in capsular regions associated with the ventrolateral and central parts of the nucleus.
A similar pattern of inputs from the MEApd to the ventromedial nucleus was reported in the hamster (see Fig. 10B in Gomez and Newman, 1992).

As in other PHAL work (Caffe et al., 1987; Gomez and Newman, 19921, we observed sparse to moderate inputs from the whole MEA to the dorsomedial nucleus and periventricular zone, where labeled terminals were found in the intermediate periventricular and arcuate nuclei.
All parts of the MEA project densely to the ventral premammillary nucleus and adjacent ventral regions of the posterior nucleus.
A robust projection to the posterior periventricular nucleus was also seen at this level, especially with PHAL injections in the MEAad.

This is confirmed by retrograde tracing experiments where more retrogradely labeled cells are seen in the MEApd than other parts of the MEA after fluorogold deposits in the ventral premammillary nucleus (N.S.
Canteras, R.B.
Simerly, and L.W.
Swanson, unpublished observations).

Our results also indicate that caudal to the ventral premammillary nucleus, labeled axons from the MEA innervate the cell-sparse capsule around the medial mammillary nucleus (containing distal dendrites of medial mammillary neurons; Cajal, 19091911) and the supramammillary nucleus.

In summary, one of the most interesting features of projections from the MEA to the hypothalamus is the striking difference between those arising in the MEApd and those arising in other parts of the nucleus: the former supplies dense inputs to the anteroventral periventricular nucleus, central and medial parts of the medial preoptic nucleus, and ventral premammillary nucleus.

Singificantly, both the principal nucleus of the BST and posterior nucleus of the amygdala, which together with the MEApd form part of a highly interconnected circuit in the basal telencephalon (above), generate very similar hypothalamic innervation patterns (Simerly et al., 1989; Canteras et al., 1992a).

The hypothalamic sites (anteroventral periventricular nucleus, central and medial parts of the medial preoptic nucleus, and ventral premammillary nucleus) associated with this set of basal telencephalic nuclei are also highly interconnected and are characterized by dense inputs to components of the hypothalamic periventricular zone including parvicellular parts of the paraventricular nucleus, intermediate periventricular nucleus, and arcuate nucleus (Simerly and Swanson, 1988; Canteras et al., 1992b), which contain cells that express hypothalamic releasing hormones and project to the median eminence neurohemal zone (see Swanson, 1987).

The MEApd, posterior nucleus of the amygdala, and principal nucleus of the BST also receive strong feedback projections from their affiliated hypothalamic targets, especially the ventral premammillary nucleus and central medial preoptic nucleus (Simerly and Swanson, 1988; Canteras et al., 1992b).

This hodological evidence reinforces the view of a distinct circuit within the basal telencephalon that includes the MEApd, posterior nucleus of the amygdala, and principal nucleus of the BST, that is extended to include certain hypothalamic nuclei (especially the anteroventral periventricular, medial preoptic, and ventral premammillary nuclei), and that plays a significant role in controlling the output of the neuroendocrine system.

Furthermore, the ventral premammillary nucleus also receives a less dense input from other parts of the MEA and may thus represent an interface between the two differentiated subsystems associated with the MEA.

Along with a projection to the ventral premammillary nucleus, the MEAad projects densely to other hypothalamic medial zone regions including the undifferentiated medial preoptic area, lateral medial preoptic nucleus, anterior hypothalamic nucleus, capsule of the ventromedial nucleus, and tuberal nucleus.
The MEApv also projects to medial zone nuclei at preoptic, anterior, and tuberal levels, although the overall pattern of terminal fields is distinct from that from the MEAad.

Most obviously, the MEApv projects much less to the medial preoptic region and projects significantly to the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, and dorsomedial and ventrolateral ventromedial nucleus (and its capsule).
Previous hodological work suggests that hypothalamic medial zone structures receiving dense inputs from the MEAad and MEApv are involved in two partly segregated intrahypothalamic circuits.

One includes the undifferentiated part of the medial preoptic area and lateral medial preoptic nucleus, along with the ventrolateral part of the the ventromedial nucleus and tuberal nucleus, and the other includes the anterior hypothalamic nucleus and dorsomedial and central parts of the ventromedial nucleus (Simerly and Swanson, 1988; Canteras et al., 1994; Risold et al., 1994).
Interestingly, the MEAad heavily innervates the former circuit, whereas the MEApv innervates preferentially the latter.

The specific functional roles played by these two medial hypothalamic circuits are still unclear, although considerable evidence suggests that the former helps mediate reproductive behavior, whereas the latter circuit appears essential for the expression of defensive/ aggressive behavior (see Lehman et al., 1980; Simerly and Swanson, 1988; Canteras et al., 1994; Risold et al., 1994).

Apart from the ventral premammillary nucleus, all of the hypothalamic medial zone targets of the MEAad and MEApv send a massive, topographically organized projection to the periaqueductal gray, which is known to play a pivotal role in the expression of several motivated behaviors (see Simerly and Swanson, 1988; Rizvi et al., 1992; Canteras et al., 1994; Risold et al., 1994).

The evidence thus indicates that the MEApd is associated with parts of the hypothalamus involved most directly with neuroendocrine regulation, whereas the MEAad, MEApv, and perhaps MEAav, project to hypothalamic medial zone regions involved in mediating reproductive and defensive behaviors.
Thus, it may be convenient to divide provisionally the MEA into two broad divisions, ventral and dorsal.

The dorsal division includes the MEApd, and its major descending projections to the hypothalamus end in the anteroventral periventricular nucleus, medial and central parts of the medial preoptic nucleus, and ventral premammillary nucleus, which play a major role in neuroendocrine regulation.

The ventral division of the MEA includes the MEAad, MEAav, and MEApv, and its major projections to the hypothalamus end in medial zone nuclei related primarily to modulating reproductive and defensive behaviors.

It is possible that the ventral division is further divided into parts that related more to reproductive (MEAad) or aggressive (MEAav and MEApv) behavior (the MEAav innervates dorsomedial and ventral parts of the ventromedial nucleus, like the MEApv).

The ventromedial nucleus receives a massive input from the ventral component of the MEA, and projects massively to the same parts of the BST (especially transverse and fascicular nuclei) and substantia innominata that receive inputs from the ventral component (Grove, 1988a; Canteras et al., 1994).
Whereas the ventromedial nucleus does not project substantially to the MEA, its amygdalar projections resemble those described here for the MEAad and MEApv (Canteras et al., 1994).

Thus, the ventromedial nucleus may provide feedback information to the basal telencephalic nuclei associated with the ventral component of the MEA, just as the ventral premammillary nucleus may provide feedback information to basal telencephalic nuclei associated with the dorsal component (see above).
Confirming Gomez and Newman (1992) in the hamster, a projection was observed from the MEAad to a caudal region of the lateral hypothalamic area adjacent to the cerebral peduncle.

This region receives olfactory information from several terminal fields of the lateral olfactory tract (Price et al., 19911, and an input from the central nucleus of the amygdala (Krettek and Price, 1978a).
Projections to the thalamus.

Significant projections to the thalamus, mainly directed toward the midline nuclei, were found after injections centered in the MEAad and MEApv, in contrast to the MEApd, which projects lightly to the thalamus.

After MEAad injections, we observed a strikingly dense plexus of labeled fibers in rostroventral parts of the nucleus reuniens, a substantial projection to the paraventricular and medial part of the mediodorsal nuclei, and a sparse input to the parataenial nucleus, lateral habenula, and subparafascicular nucleus.
The pattern of thalamic inputs from the MEApv is reminiscent of that just described from the MEAad.

The MEApv also provides a significant, but far less dense, projection to the rostroventral nucleus reuniens, and a very sparse input to the paraventricular nucleus, although it does not appear to innervate the mediodorsal nucleus.

Projections from the MEA to the nucleus reuniens, paraventricular nucleus, and medial mediodorsal nucleus have been labeled in retrograde tracer experiments (Siege1 et al., 1977; Herkenham, 1978; McDonald, 1987; Chen and Su, 19901, and a similar pattern of thalamic projections from rostral parts of the MEA was reported in the hamster (Gomez and Newman, 1992).

As discussed, the MEA projects directly to several areas of the hippocampal formation, and another potentially significant way for the MEA to access the hippocampal formation is by way of inputs from the nucleus reuniens (Herkenham, 1978; Wyss et al., 1979; Swanson et al., 1987; Su and Bentivoglio, 1990; Wouterlood et al., 1990).

Similar labeling patterns in the nucleus reuniens arise in the anterior and ventromedial hypothalamic nuclei (Canteras et al., 1994; Risold et al., 19941, which constitute major hypothalamic recipients of projections from the MEA.

Other midline thalamic nuclei receiving inputs from the MEA, especially the paraventricular nucleus, confirm important indirect links between the MEA and nucleus accumbens (Su and Bentivoglio, 1990; Berendse and Groenewegen, 19901, even if direct projections from the MEA to this part of the ventral striatum are limited.
Finally, inputs to the medial mediodorsal nucleus may provide an indirect route for MEA information to reach the prefrontal cortex (Groenewegen, 1988).
Projections to the bruinstem.
The MEA provides limited inputs to the brainstem.

Our work revealed a small group of axons from the MEA that courses through (and to) the posterior hypothalamic nucleus into periependymal regions of the periaqueductal gray; some of these fibers, especially from the MEAad and MEApv, provide a sparse input to the dorsal raphe nucleus.
Projections from the MEA to the periaqueductal gray and dorsal raphe nucleus have been reported (Caffe et al., 1987).

After PHAL injections in the MEAad we also found that some axons coursing through the lateral hypothalamic area extend caudally into the midbrain, where they provide a sparse input to the ventral tegmental area, and to the interfascicular, rostral linear, and central linear raphe nuclei.
Possible neurotransmitters

Several neuropeptides are expressed by MEA neurons: cholecystokinin (Roberts et al., 1982; Simerly and Swanson, 1987; Micevych et al., 1988; Simerly et al., 19891, substance P (Roberts et al., 1982; Simerly et al., 19891, vasopressin (Caffe and Van Leeuwen, 1983; Urban et al., 1990), corticotropin releasing hormone (Swanson et al., 1983; Sakanaka et al., 19861, angiotensin (Lind and Ganten, 1990), somatostatin (Roberts et al., 1982; McDonald, 19891, and neuropeptide Y (McDonald, 1989); and some differences between the hamster and rat have been reported.
Many MEA neurons in the hamster but not rat express tyrosine hydroxylase (Asmus et al., 1992) and prodynorphin (Neal et al., 1989).

Importantly, cholecystokinin, substance P, and angiotensin are expressed almost entirely within the MEApd (Simerly and Swanson, 1987, Simerly et al., 1989, Lind and Ganten, 19901, whereas neurons expressing corticotropin releasing hormone are mainly distributed throughout other parts of the nucleus (Swanson, et al., 1983; Sakanaka et al., 1986).

In contrast, neurons expressing somatostatin and neuropeptide Y apparently display little preferential distribution within the nucleus (McDonald, 1989), and vasopressin is localized primarily to the MEAad (Urban et al., 1990).

MEA neurons expressing cholecystokinin, substance P, and somatostatin project to the hypothalamus, and those expressing somatostatin probably innervate the BST as well (McDonald, 1987; Simerly et al., 1989).
Vasopressinergic neurons in the MEA project to the lateral septa1 nucleus and ventral hippocampus (Caffe et al., 1987).
Most of the peptides just listed also are expressed in parts of the BST that receive massive inputs from the MEA (Woodhams et al., 1983; Ju et al., 1989).
In particular, the principal nucleus of the BST and the MEApd, which share massive bidirectional connections, contain many neurons expressing cholecystokinin (Ju et al., 1989; Simerly et al., 1989).

Many neurons throughout the MEA express glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) mRNA (Okamura et al., 1990) and almost certainly contribute to the dense GABAergic innervation of the BST (see Sun and Cassell, 1993).

It has also been suggested that certain fibers arising in the MEA contain high levels of zinc (Perez-Claussell et al., 1989), which may be associated with pools of excitatory amino acid neurotransmitters (Frederickson and Danscher, 1990).
Neural inputs to the MEA
The MEA receives its major neuronal input from the accessory olfactory bulb and is thus dominated by pheromonal inputs from the vomeronasal organ (above).
Three other regions are also innervated directly by the accessory olfactory bulb (Scalia and Winans, 1975), and each projects to the MEA as well.

These regions include the bed nucleus of the accessory olfactory tract (Ottersen, 19821, posteromedial cortical nucleus (Ottersen, 1982; Canteras et al., 1992a), and BST (Swanson and Cowan, 1979; Ottersen, 1980).

It was noted above that several areas receiving direct input from the main olfactory bulb project to the MEA (anterior and posterolateral cortical nucleus, piriformamygdaloid area, and perhaps piriform area andlor the associated endopiriform nucleus).
Except for the accessory bulb, there is limited information about the possible topographic distribution of these olfactory-related inputs to the MEA.

However, most appear to be widely distributed, except for the anterior and posterolateral cortical nucleus, which project much more strongly to the MEAad, and the main olfactory bulb, which at most innervates the rostral tip of the MEAad.

Considered together, the evidence suggests that the MEA receives inputs from both the accessory (direct) and main (indirect) olfactory bulbs, and sends centrifugal projections back to many regions along these two interrelated sensory systems.
The MEAad and MEApv also receive inputs from the ventral subiculum (Ottersen, 1982; Canteras and Swanson, 19921, and project to the ventral subiculum.

These bidirectional projections interrelate the ventral division of the MEA with the intrahippocampal circuit (see Swanson et al., 1987) and could thus play a role in learning and memory associated with behaviors mediated in part by the MEA.
Many subcortical regions project to the MEA, and with several important exceptions, all of them receive inputs from the MEA.

In or adjacent to the telencephalon, the substantia innominata projects to the MEA (Ottersen, 1980; Grove, 1988b1, as do the closely associated magnocellular preoptic nucleus (Swanson, 1976; Ottersen, 1980) and lateral preoptic area (Swanson, 1976; Ottersen, 1980; Simerly and Swanson, 19881.
These projections appear to be relatively weak.

Furthermore, parts of the BST receiving inputs from the MEA send fibers back to the MEA (Swanson and Cowan, 1979; Ottersen, 1980), although the topography and strength of BST-MEA projections are unclear.
Except for the anteroventral periventricular nucleus (Simerly and Swanson, 19881, parts of the hypothalamus receiving inputs from the MEA also project to the MEA.

This includes a projection from the central medial preoptic nucleus to the MEApd (see Ottersen, 1980; Simerly and Swanson, 19881, a light projection from the anterior nucleus (primarily the central part) to all parts of the MEA (Conrad and Pfaff, 1976; Risold, et al., 19941, a light projection from all parts of the ventromedial nucleus to all parts of the MEA (Conrad and Pfaff, 1976; Saper et al., 1976; Krieger et al., 1979; Canteras et al., 19941, a light projection from the tuberal nucleus to all parts of the MEA (Ottersen, 1980; Canteras et al., 19941, a dense projection from the ventral premammillary nucleus to the MEApd (Canteras et al., 1992a), a projection from the arcuate and posterior periventricular nuclei to the MEApd (Krieger et al., 1979; Ottersen, 19801, and a projection from the posterior nucleus (Ottersen, 1980).
Two thalamic regions innervate the MEA.

First, the MEAad in particular projects to the paraventricular and parataenial nuclei and nucleus reuniens, and all three send a light project,ion to most of the MEA Weening, 1978; Ottersen and Ben-Ari, 1979; Ohtake and Yamada, 1989).

And second, a very heterogeneous region surrounding the ventral nucleus of the medial geniculate body, including the parvicellular subparafascicular nucleus, peripeduncular nucleus, medial nucleus of the medial geniculate body, suprageniculate nucleus, and posterior complex contains retrogradely labeled neurons after HRP injections in the MEA (Ottersen and Ben-Ari, 19791, and projections from this general region have been confirmed anterogradely (Jones et al., 1976; LeDoux et al., 1990a,b).

This general region is not innervated by the MEA and may relay auditory, tactile, nociceptive, and/or thermal information to the MEA (see Bordi and LeDoux, 1994; Dado et al., 1994), including sensory information related to sexual behavior (see L6pez and Carrer, 1985).
Brainstem inputs to the MEA are limited.

Medial regions of the lateral parabrachial nucleus project to the MEA (Saper and Loewy, 1980; Ottersen, 1981; Bernard et al., 1993), a pathway that, along with one from the region around the medial geniculate body, may relay sensory information from the spinal cord to the MEA (including from the genital region; Rowe and Erskine, 1993).
In addition, the parabrachial nucleus probably relays information from the vagus and/or glossopharyngeal nerves to the MEA (Herbert and Saper, 1990).
Sparse inputs to the MEA also arise in the dorsal raphe nucleus and superior central nucleus (Azmitia and Segal, 1978; Ottersen, 19811, and in the locus ceruleus (Jones and Moore, 1977).

Broadly speaking, the MEA receives massive inputs from the olfactory system, and modest inputs from parts of the basal telencephalic nuclei that receive inputs from the amygdala, from parts of the hypothalamus involved in modulating the neuroendocrine system as well as sexual and agonistic behaviors, and from parts of the thalamus and dorsal pons that relay somatic and visceral information from the spinal cord and from the 9th and 10th cranial nerves.
Seemingly light projections also arise in the midline thalamus, and in certain aminergic brainstem cell groups, including the midbrain raphe and locus ceruleus.
Hormonal regulation of MEA circuitry: sexual dimorphism

The MEA contains a substantial population of neurons concentrating estrogen and/or testosterone (Pfaff and Keiner, 1973; Sar and Stumpf, 19751, and mRNAs encoding the androgen and estrogen receptors are expressed at relatively high levels (Simerly et al., 1990).
Neurons throughout the nucleus express abundant androgen receptor mRNA, whereas estrogen receptor mRNA is abundant in the MEApd, and weakly expressed elsewhere in the nucleus (Simerly et al., 1990).

As in most other parts of the CNS that express estrogen receptor, the MEA displays clear structural and biochemical sexual dimorphisms induced by gonadal steroid hormones during a perinatal critical period (Segovia and Guillamon, 1993).
The MEA is some 20% larger in males, although sex differences in volume are maximal in the MEApd, which may be about twice as large in males (Hines eta]., 1992).

Gonadal steroids influence the expression of peptides, including cholecystokinin (Simerly and Swanson, 1987; Micevych et al., 1988, Oro et al., 1988; Simerly et al., 19891, vasopressin (De Vries et al., 1985; De Vries and Al Shamma, 1990; Urban et al., 19911, and somatostatin (Baldino et al., 19881, in MEA perikarya.

In male and female rats, gonadal steroids increase levels of cholecystokinin peptide and mRNA, and this effect occurs within physiological limits because cholecystokinin levels vary systematically during the estrous cycle (Simerly et al., 1987; Oro et al., 1988).

Furthermore, at least some neurons in the MEApd that project to the medial preoptic nucleus coexpress cholecystokinin and substance P, and estrogen influences levels of preprocholecystokinin mRNA but not preprotachykinin (which encodes substance P) mRNA in these neurons (Simerly et al., 1989).

This evidence suggests that the ratio of cholecystokinin and substance P within individual neurons of the MEApd that project to the hypothalamus varies systematically during the estrous cycle, and that such biochemical switching may play a role in altering the flow of information through sexually dimorphic circuitry.

Several MEA targets also contain many gonadal steroidconcentrating neurons (Pfaff and Keiner, 1973; Sar and Stumpf, 19751, express mRNAs encoding the androgen and/or estrogen receptors (Simerly et al., 19901, and display structural and/or biochemical sex differences (see Simerly and Swanson, 1988; Canteras et al., 1992b).
In rodents, these regions are dominated by inputs from the vomeronasal organ, are highly interconnected, and have been referred to as the sexually dimorphic circuit (see Simerly et al., 1989).

As with the MEApd, the principal nucleus of the BST contains more cholecystokinin and substance P cell bodies in males (Micevych et al., 1988; Simerly et a]., 1989); it is about twice as large in males (Hines et a]., 1992); and gonadal steroids influence cholecystokinin but not substance P levels (Simerly et al., 1989).

The MEApd and principal nucleus of the BST contain neurons where testosterone is not converted to estrogen, implying that these cell groups are important for direct influences of androgen on the rat brain (Sheridan, 1979).
The medial preoptic nucleus also receives a massive input from the MEA, and levels of cholecystokinin are increased in this sexually dimorphic nucleus by gonadal steroids (see Oro et al., 1988).
We have not examined MEA projections in female rats.

Previous anatomical studies in the medial preoptic nucleus and elsewhere suggest that the sexually dimorphic circuit is qualitatively similar in both sexes, while presenting quantitative differences in particular cell groupsiterminal fields (Simerly and Swanson, 1988).
The extended amygdala
Many attempts have been made over the years to clarify fundamental organizing principles of the basal telencephaIon, that is, the noncortical basal nuclei or ganglia as a whole.
The extended amygdala concept has proven useful recently in focusing attention on one aspect of this problem (deOlmos et al., 1985; Heimer et al., 1985; Alheid and Heimer, 1988; Alheid et al., 1995).
According to this view, a continuous region with caudal and rostral poles, and separate dorsal and ventral bands of neurons connecting them, forms a recognizable structural system.

The caudal pole of the extended amygdala includes the medial and central nuclei of the amygdala, the rostral pole includes medial and lateral regions of the BST, the dorsal bridge includes scattered neurons along the stria terminalis (the stria1 extension of the BST), and the ventral bridge includes scattered neurons in approximately the caudal (sublenticular) half of the substantia innominata along parts of the ansa peduncularis containing axons from the medial and central amydgalar nuclei.
There are two other important features of this concept.

First, it has been suggested that in lower vertebrates (and perhaps early in mammalian development) the central and medial amygdalar nuclei are connected with the BST through a continuous longitudinal association bundle, which is split in mammals into dorsal and ventral components by passage of the internal capsule as it expands along with the cortical mantle.
And second, it has been suggested that the extended amygdala can be divided into two parts.

One is a continuous band of similar neurons in the medial amygalar nucleus, ventromedial regions of the sublenticular substantia innominata, and medial regions of the BST (the medial amygdaloid group ), whereas the other is an adjacent, continuous band of neurons in the central amygdalar nucleus, dorsolateral regions of the sublenticular substantia innominata, and lateral regions of the BST (the central amygdaloid group ).
Several lines of evidence favor this hypothesis.

First, Johnston (1923) described a phylogenetically ancient and conserved bed of the stria terminalis, which develops in the ventral striatal (ventricular) ridge and forms a continuous group of scattered neurons along the stria terminalis from the central and medial amygdalar nuclei caudally, to the BST, nucleus accumbens, and anterior olfactory nucleus rostrally.

In addition to the stria terminalis, he described a ventral fiber system associated with the amygdala that he viewed as a rostral extension of the amygdalo-piriform association bundle coursing through Meynert s (1872) ansa peduncularis (Johnston s deep gray of the diagonal band, and our caudal substantia innominata) to the basal forebrain.
Second, it has been claimed that the medial and central amygdaloid groups are each characterized by a similar cell type.
Third, the medial and central amygdaloid groups are interconnected.
Fourth, it has been suggested that the afferent and efferent connections of each group may be rather uniform.
This is especially clear for the central amygdaloid group, all three parts of which project to certain autonomic-related parts of the brainstem, and receive inputs from them.
And fourth, the two amygdaloid groups may be characterized by certain histochemical features.
For example, the cupric silver impregnation method is said to delimit the central amygdaloid group.
