There are, however, several problems with the extended amygdala concept as now understood.

First, the substantia innominata in the modern sense (e.g., Nauta and Haymaker, 1969; Jones et al., 1976; Swanson, 1992) has been divided into a rostral, subcommissural, part referred to as the ventral pallidum (Heimer and Wilson, 1975; Heimer, 1978), and a caudal, sublenticular, part referred to as the sublenticular part of the extended amygdala (deOlmos et al., 1985; Alheid and Heimer, 1988).
This division was based on two observations.

Initially, Heimer and Wilson (1975) made the important point that the ventral striatum (the nucleus accumbens and olfactory tubercle) projects to the ventral pallidum, rostroventral to the traditional globus pallidus.

This result was based on the silver degeneration method, which showed that lesions of the ventral striatum produced degenerating terminals primarily in subcommissural regions of the substantia innominata.

Then, deOlmos et al. (1985) suggested that cells accompanying the ventral amygdalofugal pathway are located caudal to the ventral pallidum, in sublenticular parts of the substantia innominata, which they referred to as part of the extended amygdala.

However, more sensitive tracing methods (autoradiography: Swanson and Cowan, 1975; Mogenson et al., 1983; PHAL: Heimer et al., 1991) have shown that the nucleus accumbens projects topographically to virtually all of the substantia innominata, not just its rostral half.

Similarly, the present results demonstrate that the medial amygdalar nucleus projects not just to the sublenticular half of the substantia innominata, but all the way to its rostral tip; and the same is true for the central amygdaloid nucleus (G.
Petrovich and L.W.
Swanson, unpublished observations).

Thus, a two-part division of the substantia innominata based on major inputs (from ventral striatum and amygdala) is unjustified, and this is compounded by a lack of evidence for a division based on cytoarchitectonic criteria.

And while immunohistochemical and other staining gradients in the substantia innominata have been described (see Alheid et al., 1995), none have been used to demonstrate a clear distinction between rostral and caudal divisions.

It is also curious that the rostroventral extension of the substantia innominata (the part not actually adjacent to the globus pallidus) has been referred to as the ventral pallidum, whereas the part of the substantia innominata immediately ventral to the globus pallidus has been referred to as a part of the extended amygdala.

A second problem relates to dividing the sublenticular extended amygdala into central (dorsolateral) and medial (ventromedial) parts based on similarities of cell types in associated parts of the amygdala and BST, and on their location around fibers connecting the associated parts.

Thus, while it has been stated that cell types throughout the medial or central amygdalar groups are similar, there are as yet no formal descriptions of these neurons in the substantia innominata, so that uniform cell types within a group have not been established.

More importantly, the course of axons from the central and medial amygdalar nuclei overlap considerably in the substantia innominata on their way to the BST; they do not define two separate zones within the substantia innominata (present results and unpublished observations by G.
Petrovich and L.W.
Swanson for the central nucleus).

At the very caudal end of the substantia innominata, axons from the central nucleus clearly lie dorsolateral to those from the medial nucleus (see Fig. 3, level I), but as these fibers approach the BST (e.g., Fig. 3, levels F, G), they overlap considerably in the substantia innominata, and considerable overlap is also apparent in the rostra1 half of the substantia innominata.
Thus, there are no clear differences between medial and central parts of the extended amygdala in the substantia innominata.

Furthermore, essentially nothing is known about the morphology and connections of neurons throughout most of the stria1 extension of the BST along the course of the stria terminalis itself, the dorsal limb of the extended amygdala.
One criterion for distinguishing the central group of the extended amygdala has been the existence of bidirectional pathways with brainstem autonomic regions.

Thus, a more or less continuous band of retrograde labeling is observed in the central nucleus, sublenticular substantia innominata, and lateral regions of the BST after retrograde tracer injections in the dorsal vagal complex (e.g., Schwaber et al., 1982; Schwanzel-Fukuda et al., 1984; Grove, 1988b) and parabrachial nucleus (Moga et al., 1990).

However, this labeling is not restricted to dorsolateral parts of the sublenticular substantia innominata (it spreads ventrally, and is in fact more dense ventrally; Grove, 1988b and Fig. 6C therein; Moga et al., 1990), and it spreads medially to involve much of the lateral hypothalamic area and even paraventricular hypothalamic nucleus.
Thus, such labeling is not specific for the extended amygdala, unless the term is expanded to include the hypothalamus (and periaqueductal gray more caudally).
A third problem with the extended amygdala concept is that all parts of the amygdala, except the lateral nucleus, project to the BST (e.g., Krettek and Price, 1978a).

The current view, limiting the extended amygdala to the central and medial nuclei, appears based largely on Johnston s (1923) view that these two nuclei are phylogenetically the oldest parts of the amygdala, and thus associated with the primordial bed of the stria terminalis.
This seems an unnecessarily limiting restriction.

When other amygdalar projections to the substantia innominata are added to those from the central and medial nuclei, the already incomplete separation of this region into central and medial parts becomes even more blurred, e.g., inputs from the posterior cortical and posterior nuclei are similar, although not identical, to those from the medial nucleus (Canteras et al., 1992a).

Fourth, the view that the dorsal and ventral arms of the extended amygdala are initially part of a single fiber system (with its bed nucleus) that is later split by the developing internal capsule is provocative but unsupported by available embryological evidence.

Johnston (1923) referred to three distinct olfactory pathways associated with the amygdala (lateral olfactory tract, stria terminalis, and longitudinal association bundle), and during early forebrain vesicle development the stria terminalis extends dorsally along the sulcus terminalis (caudal edge of the telencephalic epithelial lamina), while the ansa peduncularis presumably grows rostroventrally through the pallidal (ventral striatal) ridge (Alvarez-Bollado et al., 1995).
Even the presumed early embryological continuity between the amygala, neurons along the stria terminalis, and the BST, remains to be demonstrated.
Finally, the extended amygdala concept itself might be examined.

The three distinct parts of the extended amygdala (amygdala, substantia innominata, and BST) are no doubt interconnected, but it is clear that these pathways are part of much larger circuits involving many other parts of the brain.

However, the same logic suggests the existence of an extended hippocampus (with the septal region forming a bed nucleus for the fornix), or even an extended cerebral cortex (with the basal ganglia forming a bed nucleus for the internal capsule).
A fundamental problem with extending the amygdala, or any other part of the brain, is determining how far to carry the extension in a meaningful way.

A parsimonious interpretation of the evidence can be based on the fundamental insight that the striatum and pallidum may be divided without clear boundaries into dorsal and ventral regions (Heimer and Wilson, 19751, and that the ventral striatum (nucleus accumbens, striatal fundus, and olfactory tubercle) projects topographically to the whole substantia innominata.

In this view, the substantia innominata as a whole and the ventral pallidum are synonomous, and different regions of the ventral pallidum may be dominated by topographically organized nonstriatal inputs.

In contrast, the BST is an important way station along descending pathways from the amygdala, as the adjacent lateral septal nucleus is an important way station along descending pathways from the hippocampal formation, and the striatum is an important way station along descending projections from isocortex.
Stria terminalis, fornix, and internal capsule all contain descending fibers innervating noncortical parts of the cerebral hemispheres.
